Oh!  how I love to stand on some high rock,</br>And gaze upon the foaming wild abyss</br>Of Ocean — all unshaken by the shock</br>Of billows beating 'gainst the precipice!—</br>To gaze upon the whirl, and hear the hiss</br>Of thousand surges bursting at its base!—</br>To me there is a horrid charm in this—</br>A charm to see the white foam run its race,</br>And, as one wave dissolves, another take its place.

Unbounded Ocean!  many a ship o'er thee</br>Hath swept, — and many another still shall sweep:</br>Yet of their track no traces can we see;</br>Still wildly o'er thy breast the billows leap—</br>Still over thee, unfathomable deep!</br>The surges lift their foaming crests in scorn—</br>Still over thee, the winds their revels keep;</br>And, as the gallant bark along is borne,</br>Thou closest o'er its way untrodden and untorn.

I oft have seen thee when the deep red West</br>Was mirror'd in thee, — and a glossy lake,</br>Calm and unruffled, seem'd thy peaceful breast,</br>And not an angry billow was awake,—</br>When not a breath of air was felt to shake</br>Thy quiet surface, — and the view on shore</br>Seem'd of thy gentle beauty to partake,—</br>While the serene blue sky smiled sweetly o'er,</br>And the whole scene around a heavenly aspect wore.

And I have gazed upon thee when thy waves</br>Rose up tumultously, to try their might</br>With winds and storms, — when billows left their caves</br>To swell the noises of that dreadful fight;—</br>E'en 'midst the horrors of a stormy night,</br>When surges roar'd, and the winds wildly blew,</br>I have gazed on thee with a stern delight,</br>And felt as if a part of thee, — and drew</br>More pleasure from thee as the tempest louder grew.

And I have seen thy billows madly foam,</br>And chase upon thy breast in hideous throng,</br>As if they left for ever their deep home,</br>Thy sunken rocks and hidden caves among;</br>While, as the wind wax'd stronger and more strong,</br>The roaring surges, like wild horses, rose</br>To whirl the chariot of the storm along,—</br>To deal around them shipwreck, death, and woes,</br>And rise to Heaven itself, as if its deadliest foes.

By Man the earthly wild may be reclaim'd:</br>Unmeasur'd Ocean!  who can rule o'er thee?</br>Thy waves still roll — untameable — untam'd:</br>None can control thee; — thou art wild and free:</br>No earthly power can calm thee; — thou must be</br>Kept in subjection but by One alone:—</br>HE, who once calm'd the raging of the sea,</br>And still to thee, proud Ocean!  will be known;—</br>HE holds thee in His hand, — thy might is all His own.

Thou hast thy creatures too, — a populous world</br>Of uncouth beings — monsters of the Deep,</br>That are born there and die:  thy billows curl'd,</br>Mount over caverns where the white pearls sleep;</br>And, hid within thy depths, the sea-weeds creep,</br>And grow beneath the surf that wildly raves,</br>Unmindful of the storms that o'er them leap,</br>And the rude winds that lash the dreadful waves,</br>Until, like beaten bounds, they howling seek thy caves.

Above thee glides the happy mariner,—</br>All health and life; — beneath thee is his tomb:</br>He rides upon thy waters' angry stir,</br>And little thinks of what shall be his doom:—</br>He knows not of the dreadful death to come;</br>Nor thinks, perchance, the next returning wave</br>Shall sweep him from the deck and bear him home</br>To the recesses of some coral cave,</br>That serves at once for winding-sheet, and hearse, and grave.

GOD is in every thing; — HIS voice is heard</br>In the light murmur of the water-fall—</br>In the gay music of each singing bird,</br>That tells there is a Providence o'er all;</br>But most from thee, oh Ocean!  does HE call,</br>And in thy wonders admiration claim;—</br>And where 'twixt nations stands thy liquid wall,</br>HE builds the lasting altar of his fame,</br>And writes on thee in waves His Everlasting Name.

Farewell, vast Ocean! — beautiful art thou</br>In calm and tempest: — now Calm reigns o'er thee:</br>Serene and quiet is thy glossy brow,</br>Thou glorious mirror of the Deity!</br>And how sublimely grand art thou, when HE,</br>In foaming characters, upon thy face</br>Writes His almighty anger!  Thou, proud Sea!</br>Art the wide page — the chosen tablet-place—</br>On which HE chooses His tremendous wrath to trace.

Oh Ocean!  it is o'er thy trackless way,</br>HE shews himself most mighty: — there HE wields</br>The sceptre that the winds and waves obey:—</br>HE rides in storms above thy watry fields.</br>Thou seemest most His own; — to Man HE yields</br>Part of the rule o'er earth, — but over thee</br>HE shows His anger, — and His mercy shields</br>The seaman over many a stormy sea,</br>And there sweeps many a one into Eternity.

Farewell, vast Ocean! — thou hast borne me home:—</br>Now, not a wave disturbs thy quiet breast;</br>But o'er that breast I never more shall roam,</br>For now my weary wanderings shall find rest;</br>I go to meet the beings I love best—</br>Beings from whom I've long been torn apart.</br>Yes; — I again shall see them and be blest;</br>And they shall heal the wounds of this worn heart:</br>I ne'er shall tempt thee more — tho' beautiful thou art.

Farewell! — perchance full many a year will pass,</br>Before I shall look on thy face again:—</br>Say, wilt thou be the clear pellucid glass</br>That now I leave thee? — wilt thou be so then?—</br>Or wilt thou, in thine anger and disdain,</br>Throw thy white foam upon this very spot,—</br>While o'er thee tempests shall assert their reign?</br>Thou art all silent — and thou answerest not.</br>Farewell, wide Sea! — this eve will long be unforgot.

I am not young; — my life has pass'd its prime.</br>Perhaps I ne'er again shall tread this shore.</br>Life is a billow on the sea of time</br>That, once burst, foams and rises never more:—</br>Perchance mine soon may melt amid the roar</br>Of tempests rising on that boundless sea;</br>Then will my grief and sorrow all give o'er;—</br>Then shall Life's joy or misery cease to be,</br>And I shall be resolv'd in vast Eternity.</br>
